A **helm** is a form of [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, and is one of seven armor slots available to the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") and certain [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster").

## Description

[Wearing](/wiki/Wear "Wear") a [metallic](/wiki/Metallic "Metallic") helm reduces damage from falling objects and monsters, such as:

- [falling rock traps](/wiki/Falling_rock_trap "Falling rock trap")
- boulders or rocks from a [scroll of earth](/wiki/Scroll_of_earth "Scroll of earth")
- objects [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown") upward by the hero
- falling [piercers](/wiki/Piercer "Piercer").

However, metallic helms also increase the hero's [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") failure rates, with the exception of the [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance").

A [greased](/wiki/Greased "Greased") helm may block the [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") drain damage type from a [mind flayer](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") or [master mind flayer](/wiki/Master_mind_flayer "Master mind flayer")[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) - a noncursed greased helm always blocks such an attack, while a cursed greased helm has only a 2⁄3 chance, and the grease has a 1⁄2 chance of wearing off after each blocked attack. Any helm (including a cursed greased helm that fails to provide grease protection) then has a 7⁄8 chance of blocking this attack.

### Use by monsters

Any [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that can wear armor can wear a helm;[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) a monster with [horns](/wiki/Body_parts#Horns "Body parts") can only wear [flimsy](/wiki/Flimsy "Flimsy") helms.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) If the hero or a monster is polymorphed into a form with horns while wearing a non-flimsy helm, it will be pushed off.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

[Aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest"), [high priests](/wiki/High_priest "High priest") and [minions](/wiki/Minion "Minion") will not wear a [helm of opposite alignment](/wiki/Helm_of_opposite_alignment "Helm of opposite alignment").[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

The helms with [randomized appearances](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") share four descriptions: "plumed helmet", "etched helmet", "crested helmet", and "visored helmet". Helms with the appearance of "visored helmet" protect against the [blinding](/wiki/Blind "Blind") claw attack of [ravens](/wiki/Raven "Raven") and the [blinding venom](/wiki/Blinding_venom "Blinding venom") of [cobras](/wiki/Cobra "Cobra").[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The helm of brilliance has a fixed unidentified description of "crystal helm" and is made of [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass") material, which does not inhibit spellcasting. The [helm of caution](/wiki/Helm_of_caution "Helm of caution") is a new helm with a randomized appearance that grants 1 AC and [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") when worn.

## Strategy

Unidentified helms are dangerous to wear, as two types of helms are [autocursing](/wiki/Autocursing "Autocursing") and will become cursed when a hero puts them on, even if they are noncursed. You can use [price identification](/wiki/Price_identification "Price identification") to distinguish a [dunce cap](/wiki/Dunce_cap "Dunce cap") from a [cornuthaum](/wiki/Cornuthaum "Cornuthaum"), but three of the four helms with randomized appearances have the same cost, weight and AC, making it impossible to tell them apart this way.

In the early game, any [metallic](/wiki/Metallic "Metallic") helm will protect against falling rock traps. In the later game, a greased helm protects against intelligence drain attacks; mind flayers and master mind flayers are common [genocide targets](/wiki/Genocide#Common_genocides "Genocide"), and removing them provides absolute protection.

For the [ascension kit](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit"), popular choices are:

- [helm of telepathy](/wiki/Helm_of_telepathy "Helm of telepathy") for detecting hostile monsters
- [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance") for spellcasting
- [elven leather helm](/wiki/Elven_leather_helm "Elven leather helm") for light weight and the ability to be safely enchanted to +7.

For a Wizard, a [cornuthaum](/wiki/Cornuthaum "Cornuthaum") provides [clairvoyance](/wiki/Clairvoyance "Clairvoyance") and can be safely enchanted to +7.

A helm of opposite alignment has a niche use for mitigating the [mysterious force](/wiki/Mysterious_force "Mysterious force") on the [ascension run](/wiki/Ascension_run "Ascension run"), and is more popularly used for reducing the number of altars to visit on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane").

## Variants

### SporkHack

[SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack") adds three new helms in the [gnomish helm](/wiki/Gnomish_helm "Gnomish helm"), the [helm of discovery](/index.php?title=Helm_of_discovery\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Helm of discovery (page does not exist)") and the [helm of clarity](/index.php?title=Helm_of_clarity\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Helm of clarity (page does not exist)"), as well as three new appearances: "little red hat" (always used for gnomish helms), "viking helmet" (which is randomized and has no effect), and "tinfoil hat" (which is randomized and always blocks telepathy and [psi bolts](/wiki/Psi_bolt "Psi bolt") - this includes its own telepathy if it is the appearance for a helm of telepathy).

### UnNetHack

[UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") adds a single new helm in the [tinfoil hat](/wiki/Tinfoil_hat "Tinfoil hat"), which is represented as its own item rather than a randomized appearance as in SporkHack.

Description

  • falling rock traps
  • boulders or rocks from a scroll of earth

  • falling piercers.

However, metallic helms also increase the hero's spellcasting failure rates, with the exception of the helm of brilliance.

Any helm (including a cursed greased helm that fails to provide grease protection) then has a 7⁄8 chance of blocking this attack.

Any monster that can wear armor can wear a helm;[2] a monster with horns can only wear flimsy helms.[3] If the hero or a monster is polymorphed into a form with horns while wearing a non-flimsy helm, it will be pushed off.[4]

Aligned priests, high priests and minions will not wear a helm of opposite alignment.[5]
